key_insight: MemFlow introduces a content-adaptive, flowing memory that selects and passes forward only the most relevant historical cues for each upcoming video chunk, enabling consistent long-range narrative generation without fixed compression strategies.
problem_solved: Maintains content consistency across long streaming video by replacing rigid, predefined memory compression with a dynamic memory design that adapts which historical information is preserved and used for each new segment.
method: Adaptive memory selection: before generating the next chunk, dynamically identify which past cues are most relevant to the upcoming content
Flowing memory updates: propagate selected, compressed cues forward in a stream-like memory structure so each chunk accesses a tailored history
Efficient retrieval-integration: combine compact, content-aware memory with the generation model to reduce compute/memory while preserving long-term consistency
impact: Enables more coherent and scalable streaming video generation by improving long-context consistency and efficiencyâ€”useful for real-time video synthesis, story continuation, and long-form video modeling.
visual_elements: Memory flow diagram: nodes for video chunks with arrows showing adaptive selection and propagation of cues
Timeline comparison: fixed-compression baseline vs. MemFlow showing preserved details over long context
Efficiency chart: memory usage and latency reductions vs. baseline
Qualitative frames panel: example long-video frames highlighting reduced drift and improved consistency
paper_title: MemFlow: Flowing Adaptive Memory for Consistent and Efficient Long Video Narratives
paper_authors: Sihui Ji, Xi Chen, Shuai Yang, Xin Tao, Pengfei Wan
